1.instructions:
Welcome!  We are interested in situations people experience and what they do in them.  You will describe a situation you experienced recently and what you did in that situation. You will also be asked some questions about your attitudes and values.  Based on these responses, when you have completed the study, you will be given the option to receive information about your personality that we hope you will find interesting. The following will take less than an hour to complete. 
 
To begin, please answer a few questions about yourself.

11.label: What were you doing at this time?

14.label: Approximately what time did this experience begin?

13.label: Who else was present? (If you were alone, please write âaloneâ).

instructions.thirdSection: Please type your responses in the boxes below.
instructions.secondSection: Any experience you had yesterday will do; it is only important that you remember it well. Specifically, please describe what you were doing, where you were, and who was present.
instructions.firstSection: Please describe an experience yesterday that you remember well.

thankyou.instructions: You may now exit the study, or proceed to receive some information about your personality based on the surveys you completed.
thankyou.title: Thank you!

feedback.title: Your Personality
feedback.hiAgree: High scorers tend to be considerate and polite in social interactions, and enjoy cooperating with others. They find it easy to trust people, and feel compassion for those in need. High scorers tend to be well liked by their peers, and they establish satisfying and stable close relationships. They are more likely to be religious, to serve in community leadership roles, and to do volunteer work. Older adults tend to score higher than younger adults.
feedback.secondSection: On each trait, scores above 60 can be considered high, and scores below 40 can be considered low. Descriptions of high and low scorers appear below. If your score is between 40 and 60, then your personality would probably be described as about average on the attributes listed.
feedback.loExtra: Low scorers tend to be socially and emotionally reserved. They generally prefer to be alone or with a few close friends, and keep their opinions and feelings to themselves. They are less likely to engage in thrill-seeking activities or risky behaviors such as smoking and alcohol consumption.
feedback.hiConsc: High scorers tend to be organized and responsible. They work hard to achieve their goals, and complete tasks they have begun. High scorers tend to earn higher grades in school, and perform better in many occupations. They are more likely to be religious and hold conservative political attitudes. They tend to exercise more, have better physical health, and live longer. Older adults tend to score higher than younger adults.
feedback.firstSection: Based on decades of research, personality researchers agree that the most important individual differences in personality traits are described by five basic traits known as the âBig Fiveâ: Extraversion, Agreeableness, Conscientiousness, Emotional Stability, and Openness to Experience. The measures you just completed provide scores on each of these traits and your results are described below.
feedback.loAgree: Low scorers express themselves directly and bluntly, even at the risk of starting an argument. They enjoy competition, and tend to be skeptical of other people's intentions. Low scorers tend to earn higher salaries, and are more likely to engage in some risky behaviors, such as smoking and aggressive driving.
feedback.loConsc: Low scorers tend to act spontaneously rather than making plans, and find it easier to look at the big picture than pay attention to details. They prefer to jump between tasks, instead of finishing one at a time. They tend to engage in more risky behaviors, such as smoking, alcohol consumption, and drug use.
feedback.hiExtra: High scorers tend to be talkative and energetic. They like being around people, and are comfortable asserting themselves in a group. High scorers tend to have more friends and dating partners, and are seen as more popular. They are more likely to serve in community leadership roles, and to do volunteer work. They tend to prefer energetic music, exercise more frequently, and are more likely to play a sport. They experience more frequent positive emotions, and react more strongly to positive events.
feedback.loOpen: Low scorers tend to be traditional, practical, and like to stick with traditional ways of doing things. They prefer the familiar over the new, and the concrete over the abstract. Low scorers tend to prefer, and do better in, conventional and practical occupations such as crafts and trades.
feedback.hiOpen: High scorers are generally open to new activities and new ideas. They tend to be creative, intellectually curious, and sensitive to art and beauty. High scorers tend to prefer, and do better in, scientific and artistic occupations. They prefer classical, jazz, blues, and rock music.
feedback.hiNeurot: High scorers tend to be emotionally stable and resilient. They usually stay calm, even in stressful situations, and can quickly bounce back from negative events. People who score high on emotional stability tend to feel a greater sense of well-being.
feedback.loNeurot: Low scorers tend to be emotionally sensitive, and have up-and-down mood swings. They experience more frequent negative emotions, and react more strongly to negative events. Younger adults tend to score lower than older adults.
feedback.thirdSection: We hope you enjoyed your participation in this study.

item.differentRoles: People who are present occupy different social roles or levels of status.
item.convinceYou: Someone is trying to convince you of something.
item.family: Family is important in this situation.
item.abusedVictimized: You are being abused or victimized.
item.happeningOnce: Many things are happening at once.
item.moralIssues: Moral or ethical issues are relevant.
item.jobDone: A job needs to be done.
item.tenseUpset: The situation could make people tense and upset.
item.notClear: It is not clear what is going on; the situation is uncertain.
item.hostile: The situation could make people feel hostile.
item.positiveEmotions: The situation could arouse positive emotions.
item.feelInadequate: The situation could make you feel inadequate.
item.blaming: Someone is blaming you for something.
item.ambition: Ambition can be expressed or demonstrated.
item.SomoneCountedon: Someone present (other than you) is counted on to do something.
item.closeRelationships: The people who are present have close personal relationships with each other.
item.honor: A matter of honor is at stake.
item.youFocus: You are the focus of attention.
item.politics: Politics are relevant (for example: a political discussion).
item.competing: People are competing with each other.
item.desiresGratified: Desires could be gratified (for example, food, shopping, sexual opportunities).
item.physicallyUncomfortable: The situation is physically uncomfortable (for example: too hot, too crowded, too cold, etc.). (Low placement implies the situation is physically very comfortable.)
item.complimentingYou: Someone is complimenting or praising you.
item.humorous: The situation is humorous or potentially humorous.
item.sensations: Sensations are important (for example: touch, taste, smell, physical contact).
item.clearRules: Clear rules define appropriate behavior (whether or not the rules are being followed).
item.noisy: The situation is noisy (low placement means the situation is very quiet).
item.music: Music is an important part of this situation.
item.intellectuallyStimulating: The situation could be intellectually stimulating.
item.conformToOthers: You are being pressured to conform to the actions of others.
item.askingYou: Someone is asking you for something.
item.comparingThemselves: People are comparing themselves to each other.
item.frustrating: The situation is frustrating (for example: a goal is blocked).
item.athleticsSports: People are participating in athletics or sports.
item.takenCareOf: Someone needs to be taken care of.
item.art: Art is an important part of the situation.
item.romanticPartners: Potential or actual romantic partners (for you) are present.
item.religion: Religion is relevant in this situation (for example: a religious service or discussion).
item.verbalFluency: There are opportunities to display verbal fluency (for example: a debate, a monologue, an active conversation).
item.goodImpression: It is important for you to make a good impression.
item.unusualIdeas: Unusual ideas or points of view are being discussed freely.
item.assertivenessGoal: Assertiveness is required to accomplish a goal.
item.intelligence: Intelligence is important (for example: an intellectual discussion, a complex problem that needs to be solved).
item.ruminateDaydream: It is possible to ruminate, daydream or fantasize.
item.peopleGetAlong: It is important for people to get along.
item.oppositeSex: The presence of members of the opposite sex is an important part of this situation.
item.tryingImpress: Someone is trying to impress you.
item.relevantHealth: The situation is relevant to your health (for example: possibility of illness, a medical visit).
item.selfControl: Self-control is necessary (for yourself or others).
item.simpleClearcut: The situation is simple and clear-cut.
item.decision: A decision needs to be made.
item.food: Food is important in this situation.
item.dominate: Someone is attempting to dominate or boss you.
item.countingOnYou: Someone is counting on you to do something.
item.negativeEmotions: The situation could arouse negative emotions.

2.instructions: Now, please describe the situation more precisely. From the three boxes, please place the items into nine boxes. You can drag and drop items from one box to another, but if you leave too many items in any one box, the heading will turn red.  The heading will turn green when the right number of items is in the box.

1.instructions: Now please describe the situation you experienced in more detail. 90 items will appear one at a time.  Place each item into one of three boxes.  Use the âCharacteristicâ box on the right for items that accurately describe the situation; use the âUncharacteristicâ box on the left for items that are undescriptive of the situation, and use the âNeutralâ box for items that are irrelevant, unclear, or about which you are uncertain.  When you are finished, press âContinue.â

consent.title: Consent to Participate in Research
consent.secondSection: All of your responses will be confidential and identified only by a number (and not by your name).  For research purposes, these anonymous data may be archived in an online database maintained by the Center for Open Science (www.cos.io). Each question must be answered in order to complete this survey, but you can discontinue your participation at any time without penalty.  The potential benefits of this research include improving the understanding of persons and their lives across cultural contexts.  There are no known risks.
consent.firstSection: Welcome to our study.  Your participation will be in one session and will take less than one hour. You will be asked to describe a situation you experienced recently and your behaviors in it. You will also be asked some questions about your values and attitudes.  At the end of the study, if you choose, you will receive personalized information about your personality.
consent.checkboxLabel: I have read and understand the above statements and agree to participate.
consent.thirdSection: If you have any questions about this study or your rights as a participant, you may contact [local collaboratorâs name, email and affiliation], who is responsible for data collection at your location, or the University of California, Riverside, Office of Research Integrity by email at IRB@ucr.edu. We sincerely appreciate your cooperation.
